Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"mode division multiplexing\" and \"optical integrated circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. This is a network\u2010level primitive (purification), generalizable to many pairs and MDM channels.\n  3) MDM\u2010based multi\u2010hop coded distribution: embed a small network coding protocol across two MDM channels\u2014complex but conceptually similar to prior network coding ideas.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus\u2010feasibility:\n  \u2022 Idea 2 (purification) has not appeared in the existing list (no purification protocols). It\u2019s a bona fide network transformation (two inputs \u2192 one output). Pytheus can handle two pair sources, linear\u2010optics interferometer, ancilla detectors, removed_connections, post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2022 Ideas 1 & 3 either duplicate prior setups or verge on network coding, which was already dismissed.\n\nStep 3: Select the purification idea.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus target has implemented entanglement purification\u2014i.e. a linear\u2010optics transformation of two probabilistic Bell pairs into one higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair\u2014using MDM to carry two entangled pairs in parallel within a single waveguide.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible with Pytheus: define two probabilistic pair sources on two MDM modes, use an integrated\u2010circuit layout of beam splitters to implement the purification step, post\u2010select on two heralding detectors, enforce removed_connections to prevent unwanted direct pair sources, and specify the purified Bell state as the target.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nexplanation: |\n  We propose an MDM\u2010enabled entanglement\u2010purification protocol in an integrated photonic circuit. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. The scheme generalizes naturally to N parallel MDM channels (multi\u2010stage purification) and to cascaded networks of integrated purification nodes.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM\u2010Enabled Entanglement Purification on an Integrated Circuit\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_ent_purification\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[2,1],      # forbid direct S1\u2192mode3 and S2\u2192mode1\n    [0,5],[2,4],      # no direct links to ancilla\n    [1,4],[3,5]\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [4,5]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors (heralding): D\u2081\u2026D\u2084  \n  End detectors:\n    \u2013 C measures modes C\u2081,C\u2082 (from S1\u2019s partner)  \n    \u2013 D measures modes D\u2081,D\u2082 (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = channels per waveguide (higher dimensional network coding).  \n  \u2013 Insert intermediate nodes for multi\u2010hop network coding.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010off between mode\u2010division overlap and resource overhead in large quantum networks.  \n\nThis experiment would illustrate the first MDM\u2010enabled quantum network coding on integrated photonics and provoke fundamental questions about capacity, routing, and entanglement distribution in future multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by Each source emits a Bell pair linking one peripheral node (A,B,C) to one of two MDM channels at the router chip. Concretely:\n    \u2013 S1 \u2192 detectors [0,6] (A\u2019s two modes: 0; router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S2 \u2192 detectors [2,6] (B\u2019s modes: 2; same router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S3 \u2192 detectors [4,7] (C\u2019s modes: 4; router mode: 7)\n  On the integrated circuit, mode-demultiplexers separate the two MDM spatial modes (6\u2192[6a,6b] and 7\u2192[7a,7b]), and a 6\u00d76 linear-optics interferometer mixes them with no direct source-to-source links. Two ancillary detectors (6 and 7) post-select on a joint measurement that heralds exactly one Bell pair emerging at one of the three node pairs. The three possible outcomes correspond to detection patterns at the peripheral detectors:\n    \u2013 \u201c110000\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between A\u2019s detectors [0,1]\n    \u2013 \u201c001100\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between B\u2019s detectors [2,3]\n    \u2013 \u201c000011\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between C\u2019s detectors [4,5]\n  This realizes a multiplexed entanglement swap (a quantum router) that uses integrated MDM and linear optics to maximize entanglement throughput over a single chip. To be novel, you must propose a new routing or coding primitive\u2014e.g. nontrivial multi\u2010party entangled states, higher\u2010order causal superpositions, or genuine multi\u2010hop coding protocols\u2014not just a hardware\u2010level variation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: explanation: |\n  We propose a delayed\u2010choice entanglement\u2010routing primitive on an integrated photonic chip using two MDM channels. Four probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources emit:\n    \u2022 S1: node A \u2194 router mode M1  \n    \u2022 S2: node B \u2194 router mode M1  \n    \u2022 S3: node C \u2194 router mode M2  \n    \u2022 S4: node D \u2194 router mode M2  \n  The chip demultiplexes modes M1\u2192[6,7] and M2\u2192[8,9] and feeds them into a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics interferometer. Four dedicated ancilla detectors post\u2010select on Bell\u2010measurement outcomes that herald one of two swap outcomes\u2014routing entanglement either A\u2013C or B\u2013D\u2014without ever fixing the choice in advance. The mixing across M1 and M2 creates a coherent superposition of the two swap operations. Detection patterns at the router\u2019s ancilla ports project the network into one of the two entangled links:\n    \u2013 \u201c10001000\u201d \u21d2 Bell pair between A (detector 0) & C (detector 4)  \n    \u2013 \u201c00100010\u201d \u21d2 Bell pair between B (detector 2) & D (detector 6)  \n  This demonstrates a quantum\u2010delayed\u2010choice in network connectivity, a fundamental test of causal indefiniteness in quantum networks. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. The scheme generalizes naturally to N parallel MDM channels (multi\u2010stage purification) and to cascaded networks of integrated purification nodes.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM\u2010Enabled Entanglement Purification on an Integrated Circuit\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_ent_purification\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[2,1],      # forbid direct S1\u2192mode3 and S2\u2192mode1\n    [0,5],[2,4],      # no direct links to ancilla\n    [1,4],[3,5]\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [4,5]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The scheme is just a straightforward linear\u2010optics parity\u2010check purification (two input Bell pairs, 50:50 beamsplitters, herald click \u2192 higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair) wrapped in an MDM hardware veneer. Parity\u2010check entanglement purification via linear optics already dates back to Pan\u2010style protocols and even the ensemble\u2019s \u201cIndefinite\u2010Order Entanglement Purification\u201d covers the basic idea plus new causal features. Simply using mode\u2010division multiplexing does not introduce a new network coding or causal primitive, nor does it go beyond existing one\u2010shot purification targets.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your proposal reduces to a standard two\u2010copy parity measurement purification implemented with MDM. Parallel entanglement swapping: two Bell\u2013pair sources send qubit pairs over two MDM modes in a single waveguide. An integrated multi\u2010mode circuit demultiplexes the modes and performs two simultaneous Bell\u2010state measurements, heralding two swapped entangled links in parallel.  \n  2. Mode\u2010multiplexed quantum network coding on a butterfly network: four end\u2010nodes share two Bell pairs via MDM channels; an integrated circuit at the network\u2019s bottleneck performs a joint multi\u2010mode measurement implementing quantum network coding (overlapping channels) and then heralds entanglement between the distant end pairs.  \n  3. Parallel teleportation of two unknown qubits: Alice encodes two unknown qubits in two MDM modes of a single waveguide, sends them to an integrated chip that demultiplexes and Bell\u2010measures them against two ancilla Bell pairs. Successful joint detection heralds the two teleported qubits at Bob\u2019s output ports.  \nStep 2: Novelty check & Pytheus\u2010obstacles  \n  \u2022 Idea 1 is conceptually just two parallel entanglement swaps\u2014but embedding them into one MDM circuit and sharing ancilla/detectors is new. Pytheus can design multi\u2010Bell\u2010measurements with ancillas.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 (network coding) has not been done by Pytheus; it addresses fundamental questions in quantum networks. Pytheus can handle multi\u2010party measurements and remove forbidden connections.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 (parallel teleportation) is essentially two simultaneous post\u2010selected teleportations; less network\u2010theoretic novelty.  \nStep 3: Pick the network\u2010coding idea (2).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements quantum network coding\u2014using mode\u2010division multiplexing to overlap two entanglement\u2010swapping channels in a single integrated circuit, then performing a multi\u2010mode joint measurement that achieves coded routing of entanglement. No prior Pytheus experiment has targeted network\u2010coding transformations or leveraged MDM in that way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because the network can be abstractly specified in terms of discrete modes, pair sources, beam splitters, ancilla photons, mode\u2010multiplexers/demultiplexers (linear optics), and post\u2010selected multi\u2010mode measurements. Pytheus can optimize the placement of sources, mode couplers and detectors, enforce removed_connections to prevent direct source\u2013detector links, and specify heralding detectors for the network\u2010coding measurement outcomes.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nProposed Target: \u201cMDM\u2010Enabled Quantum Network Coding on the Butterfly Topology\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider the canonical 4\u2010node butterfly network (senders A and B, receivers C and D, and a central router R). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = overlap and resource overhead in large quantum networks.  \n\nThis experiment would illustrate the first MDM\u2010enabled quantum network coding on integrated photonics and provoke fundamental Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors (heralding): D\u2081\u2026D\u2084  \n  End detectors:\n    \u2013 C measures modes C\u2081,C\u2082 (from S1\u2019s partner)  \n    \u2013 D measures modes D\u2081,D\u2082 (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = channels per waveguide (higher dimensional network coding).  \n  \u2013 Insert intermediate nodes for multi\u2010hop network coding.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010off between mode\u2010division overlap and resource overhead in large quantum networks.  \n\nThis experiment would illustrate the first MDM\u2010enabled quantum network coding on integrated photonics and provoke fundamental questions about capacity, routing, and entanglement distribution in future multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by Each source emits a Bell pair linking one peripheral node (A,B,C) to one of two MDM channels at the router chip. Concretely:\n    \u2013 S1 \u2192 detectors [0,6] (A\u2019s two modes: 0; router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S2 \u2192 detectors [2,6] (B\u2019s modes: 2; same router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S3 \u2192 detectors [4,7] (C\u2019s modes: 4; router mode: 7)\n  On the integrated circuit, mode-demultiplexers separate the two MDM spatial modes (6\u2192[6a,6b] and 7\u2192[7a,7b]), and a 6\u00d76 linear-optics interferometer mixes them with no direct source-to-source links. Two ancillary detectors (6 and 7) post-select on a joint measurement that heralds exactly one Bell pair emerging at one of the three node pairs. The three possible outcomes correspond to detection patterns at the peripheral detectors:\n    \u2013 \u201c110000\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between A\u2019s detectors [0,1]\n    \u2013 \u201c001100\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between B\u2019s detectors [2,3]\n    \u2013 \u201c000011\u201d \u2194 Bell pair between C\u2019s detectors [4,5]\n  This realizes a multiplexed entanglement swap (a quantum router) that uses integrated MDM and linear optics to maximize entanglement throughput over a single chip. Four dedicated ancilla detectors post\u2010select on Bell\u2010measurement outcomes that herald one of two swap outcomes\u2014routing entanglement either A\u2013C or B\u2013D\u2014without ever fixing the choice in advance. The mixing across M1 and M2 creates a coherent superposition of the two swap operations. Detection patterns at the router\u2019s ancilla ports project the network into one of the two entangled links:\n    \u2013 \u201c10001000\u201d \u21d2 Bell pair between A (detector 0) & C (detector 4)  \n    \u2013 \u201c00100010\u201d \u21d2 Bell pair between B (detector 2) & D (detector 6)  \n  This demonstrates a quantum\u2010delayed\u2010choice in network connectivity, a fundamental test of causal indefiniteness in quantum networks. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. Parallel entanglement swapping: two Bell\u2013pair sources send qubit pairs over two MDM modes in a single waveguide. An integrated multi\u2010mode circuit demultiplexes the modes and performs two simultaneous Bell\u2010state measurements, heralding two swapped entangled links in parallel.  \n  2. Mode\u2010multiplexed quantum network coding on a butterfly network: four end\u2010nodes share two Bell pairs via MDM channels; an integrated circuit at the network\u2019s bottleneck performs a joint multi\u2010mode measurement implementing quantum network coding (overlapping channels) and then heralds entanglement between the distant end pairs.  \n  3. Successful joint detection heralds the two teleported qubits at Bob\u2019s output ports.  \nStep 2: Novelty check & Pytheus\u2010obstacles  \n  \u2022 Idea 1 is conceptually just two parallel entanglement swaps\u2014but embedding them into one MDM circuit and sharing ancilla/detectors is new. Pytheus can handle multi\u2010party measurements and remove forbidden connections.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 (parallel teleportation) is essentially two simultaneous post\u2010selected teleportations; less network\u2010theoretic novelty.  \nStep 3: Pick the network\u2010coding idea (2).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements quantum network coding\u2014using mode\u2010division multiplexing to overlap two entanglement\u2010swapping channels in a single integrated circuit, then performing a multi\u2010mode joint measurement that achieves coded routing of entanglement. No prior Pytheus experiment has targeted network\u2010coding transformations or leveraged MDM in that way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because the network can be abstractly specified in terms of discrete modes, pair sources, beam splitters, ancilla photons, mode\u2010multiplexers/demultiplexers (linear optics), and post\u2010selected multi\u2010mode measurements. Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. pair linking Bob\u2019s mode 2   \u2194 router\u2019s MDM channel 2  \n    \u2013 SC: ancillary Bell pair linking a control qubit (mode 4) \u2194 router\u2019s MDM channel C  \n  On\u2010chip:\n superposition,\u201d projecting Alice (mode 0) and Bob (mode 2) into an entangled link under indefinite causal order, while the remaining control\u2010photon detection in D10/D11 records the     "output": "explanation: |\n  We propose an integrated\u2010photonic experiment that uses mode\u2010division multiplexing (MDM) to perform two parallel, post\u2010selected quantum teleportations over a single waveguide.  \n \n  Resources:\n    \u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters create the unknown qubits at Alice (mode 0) and Charlie (mode 2).  \n    \u2022 Two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources each emit one Bell pair: one pair between the router\u2019s MDM channel M1 and Bob (mode 1), the other between M2 and Dave (mode 3).  \n \n  On\u2010chip linear optics:\n    1. An MDM demultiplexer separates the two spatial channels M1\u2192[4,5] and M2\u2192[6,7].  \n    2. Two independent 4-mode Bell\u2010state analyzers mix:\n       \u2013 Alice\u2019s unknown (mode 0) with M1\u2019s half (mode 4) \u2192 ancilla detectors D4,D5  \n       \u2013 Charlie\u2019s unknown (mode 2) with M2\u2019s half (mode 6) \u2192 ancilla detectors D6,D7  \n    3. We post\u2010select on the \u201cidentity\u201d outcome in each analyzer (coincidence at D4&D5 and at D6&D7).  \n \n  Heralding any of these two two-click patterns simultaneously teleports Alice\u2019s qubit to Bob (mode 1) and Charlie\u2019s qubit to Dave (mode 3).  \n \n  By carrying both Bell\u2010pairs on orthogonal spatial modes in one waveguide and performing two Bell measurements in parallel on a single integrated chip, we double teleportation throughput without extra fibers. This protocol generalizes to N parallel teleportations over N MDM channels and probes the limits of multiplexed quantum\u2010network performance.  \n \nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM\u2010Multiplexed Parallel Teleportation to Two Receivers\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_parallel_teleportation\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"0000\",\"0011\",\"1100\",\"1111\"],\n    # basis: [input1,output1,input2,output2] with output_i = input_i\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5,6,7],\n  single_emitters: [0,2],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,6],[0,7],  # forbid Alice\u2019s unknown from going into Charlie\u2019s analyzer or ancilla\n    [2,1],[2,4],[2,5]   # forbid Charlie\u2019s unknown from going into Alice\u2019s analyzer or ancilla\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [4,5,6,7]\n}"

Parallel teleportation of two unknown qubits: Alice encodes two unknown qubits in two MDM modes of a single waveguide, sends them to an integrated chip that demultiplexes and Bell\u2010measures them against two ancilla Bell pairs. Successful joint detection heralds the two teleported qubits at Bob\u2019s output ports.  \nStep 2: Novelty check & Pytheus\u2010obstacles  \n  \u2022 Idea 1 is conceptually just two parallel entanglement swaps\u2014but embedding them into one MDM circuit and sharing ancilla/detectors is new. Pytheus can design multi\u2010Bell\u2010measurements with ancillas.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 (network coding) has not been done by Pytheus; it addresses fundamental questions in quantum networks. Pytheus can handle multi\u2010party measurements and remove forbidden connections.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 (parallel teleportation) is essentially two simultaneous post\u2010selected teleportations; less network\u2010theoretic novelty.  \nStep 3: Pick the network\u2010coding idea (2).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements quantum network coding\u2014using mode\u2010division multiplexing to overlap two entanglement\u2010swapping channels in a single integrated circuit, then performing a multi\u2010mode joint measurement that achieves coded routing of entanglement. No prior Pytheus experiment has targeted network\u2010coding transformations or leveraged MDM in that way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because the network can be abstractly specified in terms of discrete modes, pair sources, beam splitters, ancilla photons, mode\u2010multiplexers/demultiplexers (linear optics), and post\u2010selected multi\u2010mode measurements. Pytheus can optimize the placement of sources, mode couplers and detectors, enforce removed_connections to prevent direct source\u2013detector links, and specify heralding detectors for the network\u2010coding measurement outcomes.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nProposed Target: \u201cMDM\u2010Enabled Quantum Network Coding on the Butterfly Topology\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider the canonical 4\u2010node butterfly network (senders A and B, receivers C and D, and a central router R). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [[A\u2081,C\u2081],[A\u2082,C\u2082],[B\u2081,D\u2081],[B\u2082,D\u2082]] to forbid direct pair sources between A\u2192C and B\u2192D  \n  \u2022 single_emitters = [] (probabilistic pair sources only) channels per waveguide (higher dimensional network coding).  \n  \u2013 Insert intermediate nodes for multi\u2010hop network coding.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010off between mode\u2010division overlap and resource overhead in large quantum networks.  \n\nThis experiment would illustrate the first MDM\u2010enabled quantum network coding on integrated photonics and provoke fundamental questions about capacity, routing, and entanglement distribution in future multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your proposal duplicates the existing butterfly network-coding experiment in the ensemble (\u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201cmode division multiplexing\u201d (MDM) and \u201coptical integrated circuits\u201d into a novel, Pytheus-compatible quantum-network primitive (no state\u2010generation):\n 1) Simple parallel MDM entanglement swaps (too trivial).  \n 2) MDM-based entanglement purification (already dismissed).  \n 3) Indefinite\u2010route entanglement percolation: superpose two distinct two-hop swap paths in a single integrated chip by MDM interference.\n\nStep 2: Only (3) is both novel (no prior Pytheus experiment superposes whole routes) and feasible (uses only probabilistic pair sources, a static linear-optics MDM demux/interferometer, removed_connections, and post-selected heralding detectors).\n\nStep 3: Select (3).\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements the first MDM\u2010enabled, indefinite\u2010route entanglement percolation: a network primitive where two alternative multi-hop paths (S\u2192I\u2081\u2192R and S\u2192I\u2082\u2192R) are coherently superposed in a single static circuit, probing causal superpositions in quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because we only need to declare four probabilistic pair sources on two MDM channels, a 4\u00d74 linear-optics mixing stage (the integrated circuit), ancilla detectors for post-selection, removed_connections to forbid unwanted direct links, and a target consisting of two 4-bit output strings (\u201c1001\u201d and \u201c0110\u201d).\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nexplanation: |\n  We propose an MDM\u2010enabled \u201cindefinite\u2010route entanglement percolation\u201d primitive on a single integrated photonic chip. Two distinct two-hop paths connect Sender S to Receiver R via intermediate nodes I\u2081 and I\u2082:\n\n    Path A: S\u2192I\u2081\u2192R  \n    Path B: S\u2192I\u2082\u2192R  \n\n  Each link is a Bell pair encoded on one of two spatial modes (MDM channels) carried in the same waveguide. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources create:\n    \u2022 S\u2081: S(mode 0) \u2194 I\u2081(router in, mode 4)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082: I\u2081(router in, mode 5) \u2194 R(mode 2)  \n    \u2022 S\u2083: S(mode 1) \u2194 I\u2082(router in, mode 6)  \n    \u2022 S\u2084: I\u2082(router in, mode 7) \u2194 R(mode 3)  \n\n  On the integrated chip:\n    \u2013 Demultiplex modes 4\u2192[4a,4b], 5\u2192[5a,5b], 6\u2192[6a,6b], 7\u2192[7a,7b]  \n    \u2013 A 4\u00d74 linear-optics interferometer mixes the router inputs [4,5,6,7] so as to erase which-path information.  \n    \u2013 Two ancilla detectors (indices 8,9) post-select on a joint click pattern that projects S and R\u2019s remaining modes into a coherent superposition of having been swapped along Path A or Path B.\n\n  Heralded outcomes at S and R correspond to the two-bit strings:\n    \u2013 \u201c1001\u201d  (Bell link via I\u2081)  \n    \u2013 \u201c0110\u201d  (Bell link via I\u2082)  \n\n  Because the circuit erases which-route information, the final S\u2013R entanglement is in an indefinite superposition of the two paths\u2014implementing the first MDM\u2010multiplexed, indefinite\u2010route entanglement percolation.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"Indefinite\u2010Route Entanglement Percolation via MDM\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_indef_route_percolation\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"1001\",\"0110\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [8,9],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],  # no direct S\u2013R sources\n    [0,5],[1,7],[2,4],[3,6]   # forbid cross\u2010links to wrong router ports\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [8,9]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: \u201cMDM\u2010Enabled Quantum Network Coding on the Butterfly Topology\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider the canonical 4\u2010node butterfly network (senders A and B, receivers C and D, and a central router R). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n
