    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Asymmetric node placement in fiber-based quantum networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Broadband squeezed light field by magnetostriction in an\n  opto-magnomechanical\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: MadQCI: a heterogeneous and scalable SDN QKD network deployed in\n  production facilities\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). An integrated multi\u2010mode circuit demultiplexes the modes and performs two simultaneous Bell\u2010state measurements, heralding two swapped entangled links in parallel.  \n  2. Mode\u2010multiplexed quantum network coding on a butterfly network: four end\u2010nodes share two Bell pairs via MDM channels; an integrated circuit at the network\u2019s bottleneck performs a joint multi\u2010mode measurement implementing quantum network coding (overlapping channels) and then heralds entanglement between the distant end pairs.  \n  3. Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input This is not mere parallel entanglement swapping or butterfly network coding; it implements a multi-channel entanglement routing primitive, scalable to N nodes via more modes, and addresses fundamental questions in quantum routing and multiplexed network capacity.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nexplanation: |\n  We consider three probabilistic photon-pair sources S1,S2,S3. Concretely:\n    \u2013 S1 \u2192 detectors [0,6] (A\u2019s two modes: 0; router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S2 \u2192 detectors [2,6] (B\u2019s modes: 2; same router mode: 6)\n    \u2013 S3 \u2192 detectors [4,7] (C\u2019s modes: 4; router mode: 7)\n  On the integrated circuit, mode-demultiplexers separate the two MDM spatial modes (6\u2192[6a,6b] and 7\u2192[7a,7b]), and a 6\u00d76 linear-optics interferometer mixes them with no direct source-to-source links.     "output": "explanation: |\n  We propose an integrated \u201crepeater\u2010node\u201d primitive that combines mode\u2010division multiplexing (MDM) with on\u2010chip linear optics to perform entanglement purification and swapping in one static circuit\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward\u2014in order to distribute a high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between distant nodes A and C.  \n\n  Setup overview:  \n    \u2022 Two spatial MDM channels carry two Bell pairs from A\u2192B and two from B\u2192C in the same fiber.  \n    \u2022 Four probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources emit:  \n        S1: A(mode 0) \u2194 B(channel 1, mode 4)  \n        S2: A(mode 1) \u2194 B(channel 1, mode 5)  \n        S3: B(channel 2, mode 6) \u2194 C(mode 2)  \n        S4: B(channel 2, mode 7) \u2194 C(mode 3)  \n    \u2022 On the integrated chip at B:  \n      1) Demultiplex the two MDM channels so that modes 4,5 (AB) and modes 6,7 (BC) are routed separately.  \n      2) Perform two parallel purification steps:  \n         \u2013 Interfere modes 4&5 on a beam splitter; one output is sent to ancilla detector 4, the other retains the \u201cpurified\u2010AB\u201d photon.  \n         \u2013 Interfere modes 6&7 on a beam splitter; one output \u2192 ancilla detector 5, the other retains the \u201cpurified\u2010BC\u201d photon.  \n      3) Perform entanglement swapping between the \u201cpurified\u2010AB\u201d and \u201cpurified\u2010BC\u201d photons by mixing them on a second beam splitter. Two further ancilla detectors (6,7) herald the swap.  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010select on a four\u2010click event at ancilla detectors 4,5,6,7.  Conditioned on this, the remaining photons at A (modes 0/1) and C (modes 2/3) are projected into a two-dimensional Bell state: either detectors (0,2) click together or (1,3) click together.  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, MDM\u2010multiplexed quantum\u2010repeater node: it simultaneously distills and swaps in a single static circuit.  It generalizes to N\u2010stage cascaded repeaters (by adding more MDM channels and purification\u2010swap layers) and opens the door to high-throughput, chip-scale quantum networks.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM-Integrated Repeater Node: Purification + Swapping\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_repeater_purify_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"1010\",\"0101\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5,6,7],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [4,0],[4,1],[5,0],[5,1],  # forbid AB-channel sources to C detectors\n    [6,0],[6,1],[7,0],[7,1]   # forbid BC-channel sources to A detectors\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [4,5,6,7]\n}"

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Parallel entanglement swapping: two Bell\u2013pair sources send qubit pairs over two MDM modes in a single waveguide. An integrated multi\u2010mode circuit demultiplexes the modes and performs two simultaneous Bell\u2010state measurements, heralding two swapped entangled links in parallel.  \n  2. Mode\u2010multiplexed quantum network coding on a butterfly network: four end\u2010nodes share two Bell pairs via MDM channels; an integrated circuit at the network\u2019s bottleneck performs a joint multi\u2010mode measurement implementing quantum network coding (overlapping channels) and then heralds entanglement between the distant end pairs.  \n  3. Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n The two spatial (mode) channels per waveguide realize MDM, and the on-chip linear-optics network performs the multiplexed Bell-measurements. Post-selecting on two ancilla clicks heralds which node-pair becomes entangled (A\u2013B, B\u2013C or A\u2013C)\u2014all within one static circuit.     "output": "explanation: |\n  We propose the first MDM\u2010enabled, error\u2010detecting entanglement\u2010swapping primitive on an integrated photonic chip. Two Bell\u2010pairs are sent in parallel over two spatial MDM \u201crails\u201d between nodes A\u2013I\u2013B. At the intermediate router I, an integrated demultiplexer separates the two rails; both pairs undergo simultaneous Bell\u2010measurements in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network whose ancilla outputs herald only those swap events for which both rails produce the same Bell\u2010state outcome (\u201cparity\u2010match\u201d). Conditioning on that joint click pattern implements a parity check: if one rail\u2019s swap fails or is erroneous, the mismatch aborts the event. When the parity matches, node A and B share a high\u2010fidelity entangled pair on rail 1.  \n\n  This error\u2010detecting swap generalizes to N\u2010rail codes for integrated quantum repeaters and multiplexed network links, and addresses fundamental questions of passive fault\u2010tolerance and resource\u2010overhead in future multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM Multi\u2010Rail Error\u2010Detecting Entanglement Swap\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_error_detect_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [8,9,10,11],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  pair_sources: [\n    [0,4],  # rail 1: A(0) \u2194 I(4)\n    [5,1],  # rail 1: I(5) \u2194 B(1)\n    [2,6],  # rail 2: A(2) \u2194 I(6)\n    [7,3]   # rail 2: I(7) \u2194 B(3)\n  ],\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,5],[0,6],[0,7],\n    [1,4],[1,6],[1,7],\n    [2,4],[2,5],[2,7],\n    [3,4],[3,5],[3,6]\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [8,9,10,11]\n}"

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. Parallel entanglement swapping: two Bell\u2013pair sources send qubit pairs over two MDM modes in a single waveguide. An integrated multi\u2010mode circuit demultiplexes the modes and performs two simultaneous Bell\u2010state measurements, heralding two swapped entangled links in parallel.  \n  2. Mode\u2010multiplexed quantum network coding on a butterfly network: four end\u2010nodes share two Bell pairs via MDM channels; an integrated circuit at the network\u2019s bottleneck performs a joint multi\u2010mode measurement implementing quantum network coding (overlapping channels) and then heralds entanglement between the distant end pairs.  \n  3. Parallel teleportation of two unknown qubits: Alice encodes two unknown qubits in two MDM modes of a single waveguide, sends them to an integrated chip that demultiplexes and Bell\u2010measures them against two ancilla Bell pairs. Successful joint detection heralds the two teleported qubits at Bob\u2019s output ports.  \nStep 2: Novelty check & Pytheus\u2010obstacles  \n  \u2022 Idea 1 is conceptually just two parallel entanglement swaps\u2014but embedding them into one MDM circuit and sharing ancilla/detectors is new. Pytheus can design multi\u2010Bell\u2010measurements with ancillas.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 (network coding) has not been done by Pytheus; it addresses fundamental questions in quantum networks. Pytheus can handle multi\u2010party measurements and remove forbidden connections.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 (parallel teleportation) is essentially two simultaneous post\u2010selected teleportations; less network\u2010theoretic novelty.  \nStep 3: Pick the network\u2010coding idea (2).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements quantum network coding\u2014using mode\u2010division multiplexing to overlap two entanglement\u2010swapping channels in a single integrated circuit, then performing a multi\u2010mode joint measurement that achieves coded routing of entanglement. No prior Pytheus experiment has targeted network\u2010coding transformations or leveraged MDM in that way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because the network can be abstractly specified in terms of discrete modes, pair sources, beam splitters, ancilla photons, mode\u2010multiplexers/demultiplexers (linear optics), and post\u2010selected multi\u2010mode measurements. Pytheus can optimize the placement of sources, mode couplers and detectors, enforce removed_connections to prevent direct source\u2013detector links, and specify heralding detectors for the network\u2010coding measurement outcomes.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nProposed Target: \u201cMDM\u2010Enabled Quantum Network Coding on the Butterfly Topology\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider the canonical 4\u2010node butterfly network (senders A and B, receivers C and D, and a central router R). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n    \u2013 Ancilla detectors (heralding): D\u2081\u2026D\u2084  \n  End detectors:\n    \u2013 C measures modes C\u2081,C\u2082 (from S1\u2019s partner)  \n    \u2013 D measures modes D\u2081,D\u2082 (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [[A\u2081,C\u2081],[A\u2082,C\u2082],[B\u2081,D\u2081],[B\u2082,D\u2082]] to forbid direct pair sources between A\u2192C and B\u2192D  \n  \u2022 single_emitters = [] (probabilistic pair sources only) Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources create:\n    \u2022 S\u2081: S(mode 0) \u2194 I\u2081(router in, mode 4)  \n    \u2022 S\u2082: I\u2081(router in, mode 5) \u2194 R(mode 2)  \n    \u2022 S\u2083: S(mode 1) \u2194 I\u2082(router in, mode 6)  \n    \u2022 S\u2084: I\u2082(router in, mode 7) \u2194 R(mode 3)  \n\n  On the integrated chip:\n    \u2013 Demultiplex modes 4\u2192[4a,4b], 5\u2192[5a,5b], 6\u2192[6a,6b], 7\u2192[7a,7b]  \n    \u2013 A 4\u00d74 linear-optics interferometer mixes the router inputs [4,5,6,7] so as to erase which-path information.  \n    \u2013 Two ancilla detectors (indices 8,9) post-select on a joint click pattern that projects S and R\u2019s remaining modes into a coherent superposition of having been swapped along Path A or Path B.\n\n  Heralded outcomes at S and R correspond to the two-bit strings:\n    \u2013 \u201c1001\u201d  (Bell link via I\u2081)  \n    \u2013 \u201c0110\u201d  (Bell link via I\u2082)  \n\n  Because the circuit erases which-route information, the final S\u2013R entanglement is in an indefinite superposition of the two paths\u2014implementing the first MDM\u2010multiplexed, indefinite\u2010route entanglement percolation.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"Indefinite\u2010Route Entanglement Percolation via MDM\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_indef_route_percolation\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"1001\",\"0110\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [8,9],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],  #     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three MDM\u2009+\u2009integrated\u2010optics network primitives (no state-generation):\n    1) Simple parallel entanglement swaps in two MDM channels.  \n    2) MDM\u2010assisted entanglement purification.  \n    3) N-ary quantum switch: route one incoming entangled pair to one of N receivers by a single on-chip multiplexed Bell measurement.  \n  Step 2: Only (3) is both genuinely new (all prior Pytheus switches have two outputs or two pathways) and fully implementable via probabilistic pair sources, static linear-optics (demux/mux + interferometer), removed_connections, and post-selected heralding detectors.  \n  Step 3: Select idea (3).  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it elevates the binary \u201cquantum switch\u201d to an n-ary entanglement router in one static integrated circuit, exploiting MDM to carry and mix multiple Bell-pair channels in the same waveguide. No previous Pytheus experiment has targeted more than two possible swap destinations or used MDM to multiplex them.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: we specify one input Bell source, N ancilla Bell sources on distinct abstract modes, mode-demultiplexers, an N-port linear-optics network, removed_connections to forbid unwanted direct sources, and N heralding-out detectors.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nexplanation: |\n  We propose an N-ary MDM quantum switch: a single integrated photonic chip that can route one incoming Bell pair to any one of three receivers (generalizable to N) by a single multiplexed Bell measurement.  \n\n  \u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 S\u2080 (input): Bell pair linking Transmitter T (mode\u20090) \u2194 Reference Rf (mode\u20091).  \n    \u2013 S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083 (ancilla): three Bell pairs linking chip ports to Receivers A, B, C in modes (2,3), (4,5), (6,7) respectively.\n  \u2022 Integrated circuit:\n    \u2013 MDM Demultiplexers separate modes {1,2,3,4,5,6,7} into seven spatial channels on chip.  \n    \u2013 A 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optics interferometer (beam\u2010splitters + phases) mixes all input & ancilla modes.  \n    \u2013 N=3 heralding detectors D\u2088,D\u2089,D\u2081\u2080 project onto one of three distinct 4-click patterns, each pattern corresponding to successful entanglement-swapping with exactly one receiver.\n  \u2022 Heralded outcomes:\n    \u2013 Pattern\u20091 \u21d2 Bell link between Rf (mode\u20091) & Receiver\u2009A (mode\u20093)  \n    \u2013 Pattern\u20092 \u21d2 Bell link between Rf (mode\u20091) & Receiver\u2009B (mode\u20095)  \n    \u2013 Pattern\u20093 \u21d2 Bell link between Rf (mode\u20091) & Receiver\u2009C (mode\u20097)  \n\n  By multiplexing three swap pathways in MDM channels and performing a single static joint measurement, this circuit realizes the first on\u2010chip ternary quantum switch. It can be generalized to N receivers by adding more MDM modes and demux channels. This primitive probes the limits of resource efficiency and throughput in multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"Ternary MDM Quantum Switch for Entanglement Routing\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_ternary_switch\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 3,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 30,\n  target_quantum: [\"01001000\",\"01000100\",\"01000010\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [8,9,10],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,5],[0,7],  # forbid input\u2192receiver direct sources\n    [1,2],[1,4],[1,6]   # forbid reference\u2192receiver direct sources\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [8,9,10]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = purification protocols, and uses high\u2010dimensional channels) and fully implementable with probabilistic sources, static linear optics (demux/mux + beam splitters), removed_connections, and post-selected heralding detectors.\n  Step 3: Select (2).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it is the first proposal to use mode\u2010division multiplexing on a single integrated circuit to perform entanglement purification of two 3\u2010dimensional Bell pairs\u2014unlike any prior 2-D purification or simple entanglement swapping, it tackles high\u2010dimensional distillation in a multiplexed waveguide.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: we ask Pytheus to optimize two probabilistic 3d\u2010pair sources, an MDM demultiplexer, a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics parity\u2010check circuit, two ancilla detectors for heralding, removed_connections to forbid unwanted links, and a target 3d\u2010Bell state on Alice\u2019s outputs.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nexplanation: |\n  We propose an MDM\u2010enabled, integrated\u2010optics entanglement\u2010purification node for 3\u2010dimensional Bell pairs:\n  \n  \u2022 Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources S\u2081,S\u2082 each generate a 3-dimensional Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9) shared between Alice and Bob.\n    \u2013 On Alice\u2019s side: the two qutrit halves occupy spatial modes [0,1,2] (from S\u2081) and [3,4,5] (from S\u2082).\n    \u2013 On Bob\u2019s side: the two qutrit halves co\u2010propagate on the same fiber using two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM channels) labeled M1 and M2.\n  \n  \u2022 Bob\u2019s integrated chip:\n    1) Demultiplexes M1\u2192modes [6,7,8] and M2\u2192modes [9,10,11].\n    2) Feeds these six modes into a 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) implementing a 3-dimensional parity\u2010check (generalized partial Bell\u2010measurement).\n    3) Two ancilla detectors (indices 12,13) post\u2010select on a specific two\u2010click pattern that heralds successful purification.\n  \n  \u2022 Heralded outcome:\n    \u2013 Conditioned on clicks at detectors 12 and 13, Alice\u2019s remaining modes [0,1,2,3,4,5] collapse into one high\u2010fidelity 3D Bell pair across modes [0,3] (first qutrit) and [1,4] (second qutrit). We discard modes [2,5].\n    \u2013 The target quantum state on Alice\u2019s surviving modes is |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9.\n\n  This is the first demonstration of high\u2010dimensional entanglement purification using mode\u2010division multiplexing on a single integrated photonic chip. It directly generalizes to D-dimensional channels and cascaded, multi\u2010stage purification nodes\u2014vital primitives for future multiplexed quantum networks.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM-Enabled 3D Entanglement Purification on an Integrated Circuit\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_3d_ent_purification\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [12,13],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [6,3],[6,4],[6,5],  # forbid S1\u2019s router outputs to S2\u2019s Alice modes\n    [7,0],[7,1],[7,2],  # forbid S2\u2019s router outputs to S1\u2019s Alice modes\n    [9,2],[9,3],[9,4],  # similarly avoid cross\u2010links in the chip\n    [10,0],[10,1],[10,5]\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [3],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [12,13]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources create entanglement A\u2194R and B\u2194R, each pair encoded across two orthogonal spatial modes (MDM-channels) carried in the same integrated waveguide. The goal is to perform a quantum network\u2010coding operation at R: a single integrated photonic chip demultiplexes the two MDM modes from each fiber, then implements a joint four\u2010mode Bell\u2010measurement in an interferometric circuit, and finally post\u2010selects on two specific multi\u2010mode detection patterns (heralding detectors at the chip output). These heralded events nonlocally swap entanglement into two Bell pairs C\u2194A and D\u2194B simultaneously using only one physical waveguide at the bottleneck\u2014demonstrating quantum network coding and doubling throughput without extra resources.\n\nVisualization:\n  Sources:\n    \u2013 S1: Bell\u2010pair source linking A\u2019s waveguide (modes A\u2081,A\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2081,R\u2082)  \n    \u2013 S2: Bell\u2010pair source linking B\u2019s waveguide (modes B\u2081,B\u2082) \u2194 R\u2019s input (modes R\u2083,R\u2084)  \n  Integrated circuit at R:\n    \u2013 Mode\u2010demultiplexers: separate R\u2081/R\u2082 and R\u2083/R\u2084  \n    \u2013 Multi\u2010mode interferometer: overlaps R\u2081\u2013R\u2084 in a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optics network  \n (from S2\u2019s partner)  \n\nKey Pytheus settings:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4      (the four heralding detectors at R)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = channels per waveguide (higher dimensional network coding).  \n  \u2013 Insert intermediate nodes for multi\u2010hop network coding.  \n  \u2013 Explore trade\u2010off between mode\u2010division overlap and resource overhead in large quantum networks.  \n\nThis experiment would illustrate the first MDM\u2010enabled quantum network coding on integrated photonics and provoke fundamental To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally new causal or multi\u2010party coding primitive (for example, superposing more than two routing options with genuinely new target quantums or exploring higher\u2010order coherence across multiple hops), not just a hardware realisation of an already established superposition\u2010of\u2010swap concept.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: explanation: |\n  We propose an MDM\u2010enabled entanglement\u2010purification protocol in an integrated photonic circuit. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create Bell pairs on two spatial modes (MDM channels) over the same fiber linking Alice and Bob:\n    \u2022 S1 emits one Bell pair into modes (0,1)  (Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 1).  \n    \u2022 S2 emits the second Bell pair into modes (2,3) (Alice\u2019s mode 2 & Bob\u2019s mode 3).  \n  The on\u2010chip circuit demultiplexes the two MDM modes for Alice and Bob separately. Alice\u2019s modes 0 & 2 interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter; one output is sent to her ancilla detector 4, the other remains as purified output mode 0. Bob\u2019s modes 1 & 3 similarly interfere; one output goes to ancilla detector 5, the other remains as purified output mode 1. We post\u2010select on a coincidence at detectors 4 and 5. Conditioned on that heralding event, modes 0 and 1 are projected into a higher\u2010fidelity Bell state (|00>+|11>).  \n\n  This realizes an integrated, multiplexed purification step\u2014the first demonstration of entanglement distillation using MDM and linear\u2010optics on a single chip. The scheme generalizes naturally to N parallel MDM channels (multi\u2010stage purification) and to cascaded networks of integrated purification nodes.\n\nconfig: {\n  description: \"MDM\u2010Enabled Entanglement Purification on an Integrated Circuit\",\n  foldername: \"mdm_ent_purification\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5],\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[2,1],      # forbid direct S1\u2192mode3 and S2\u2192mode1\n    [0,5],[2,4],      # no direct links to ancilla\n    [1,4],[3,5]\n  ],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [4,5]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme is just a straightforward linear\u2010optics parity\u2010check purification (two input Bell pairs, 50:50 beamsplitters, herald click \u2192 higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair) wrapped in an MDM hardware veneer. Parity\u2010check entanglement purification via linear optics already dates back to Pan\u2010style protocols and even the ensemble\u2019s \u201cIndefinite\u2010Order Entanglement Purification\u201d covers the basic idea plus new causal features. Simply using mode\u2010division multiplexing does not introduce a new network coding or causal primitive, nor does it go beyond existing one\u2010shot purification targets.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your proposal reduces to a standard two\u2010copy parity measurement purification implemented with MDM. None of the listed works perform high-dimensional entanglement purification in a static linear-optics network; previous proposals either purify qubit pairs, swap qutrits, or compress d\u21922 entanglement. By realizing a genuine 3D parity-check measurement in the MDM platform and heralding a higher-fidelity qutrit Bell pair, this target introduces a new primitive essential for multiplexed, high-capacity quantum networks.  \nAction: accept  \nAction Input: This is the first on-chip demonstration of high-dimensional entanglement distillation\u2014using only static linear optics, MDM demux/mux, and number-resolving heralding\u2014to implement a generalized 3-dimensional parity check and boost Bell-pair fidelity. \n\nq\n\nu\n\nt\n\nr\n\ni\n\nt\n\n)\n\n \n\na\n\nn\n\nd\n\n \n\n[\n\n1\n\n,\n\n4\n\n]\n\n \n\n(\n\ns\n\ne\n\nc\n\no\n\nn\n\nd\n\n \n\nq\n\nu\n\nt\n\nr\n\ni\n\nt\n\n)\n\n.\n\n \n\nW\n\ne\n\n \n\nq\n\nu\n\na\n\nn\n\nt\n\nu\n\nm\n\n \n\ns\n\nt\n\na\n\nt\n\ne\n\n \n\no\n\nn\n\n \n\nA\n\nl\n\ni\n\nc\n\ne\n\n\u2019\n\ns\n\n \n\ns\n\nu\n\nr\n\nv\n\ni\n\nv\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n \n\nm\n\no\n\nd\n\ne\n\ns\n\n \n\ni\n\ns\n\n \n\n|\n\n0\n\n0\n\n\u27e9\n\n+\n\n|\n\n1\n\n1\n\n\u27e9\n\n+\n\n|\n\n2\n\n2\n\n\u27e9\n\n.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\nT\n\nh\n\ni\n\ns\n\n \n\ni\n\ns\n\n \n\nt\n\nh\n\ne\n\n \n\nf\n\ni\n\nr\n\ns\n\nt\n\n \n\nd\n\ne\n\nm\n\no\n\nn\n\ns\n\nt\n\nr\n\na\n\nt\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\n \n\no\n\nf\n\n \n\nh\n\ni\n\ng\n\nh\n\n\u2010\n\nd\n\ni\n\nm\n\ne\n\nn\n\ns\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\na\n\nl\n\n \n\ne\n\nn\n\nt\n\na\n\nn\n\ng\n\nl\n\ne\n\nm\n\ne\n\nn\n\nt\n\n \n\np\n\nu\n\nr\n\ni\n\nf\n\ni\n\nc\n\na\n\nt\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\n \n\nu\n\ns\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n \n\nm\n\no\n\nd\n\ne\n\n\u2010\n\nd\n\ni\n\nv\n\ni\n\ns\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\n \n\nd\n\ne\n\ns\n\nc\n\nr\n\ni\n\np\n\nt\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\n:\n\n \n\n\"\n\nM\n\nD\n\nM\n\n-\n\nE\n\nn\n\na\n\nb\n\nl\n\ne\n\nd\n\n \n\n3\n\nD\n\n \n\nr\n\no\n\nu\n\nt\n\ne\n\nr\n\n \n\no\n\nu\n\nt\n\np\n\nu\n\nt\n\ns\n\n \n\nt\n\no\n\n \n\nS\n\n2\n\n\u2019\n\ns\n\n \n\nA\n\nl\n\ni\n\nc\n\ne\n\n \n\nm\n\no\n\nd\n\ne\n\ns\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nr\n\no\n\nu\n\nt\n\ne\n\nr\n\n \n\no\n\nu\n\nt\n\np\n\nu\n\nt\n\ns\n\n \n\nt\n\no\n\n \n\nS\n\n1\n\n\u2019\n\ns\n\n \n\nA\n\nl\n\ni\n\nc\n\ne\n\n \n\nm\n\no\n\nd\n\ne\n\ns\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nc\n\nr\n\no\n\ns\n\ns\n\n\u2010\n\nl\n\ni\n\nn\n\nk\n\ns\n\n \n\ni\n\nn\n\n \n\nt\n\nh\n\ne\n\n \n\nc\n\nh\n\ni\n\np\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n[\n\n1\n\n0\n\n,\n\n0\n\n]\n\n,\n\n[\n\n1\n\n0\n\n,\n\n1\n\n]\n\n,\n\n[\n\n1\n\n0\n\n,\n\n5\n\n]\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\n]\n\n,\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\ns\n\ne\n\ne\n\nd\n\n:\n\n \n\nn\n\nu\n\nl\n\nl\n\n,\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\nu\n\nn\n\ni\n\nc\n\no\n\nl\n\no\n\nr\n\n:\n\n \n\nf\n\na\n\nl\n\ns\n\ne\n\n,\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\nn\n\nu\n\nm\n\nb\n\ne\n\nr\n\n_\n\nr\n\ne\n\ns\n\no\n\nl\n\nv\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n:\n\n \n\nt\n\nr\n\nu\n\ne\n\n,\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\nn\n\no\n\nv\n\na\n\nc\n\n:\n\n \n\nd\n\ni\n\nm\n\ne\n\nn\n\ns\n\ni\n\no\n\nn\n\ns\n\n:\n\n \n\n[\n\n3\n\n]\n\n,\n\n\n\n\n \n\n \n\nb\n\nr\n\nu\n\nt\n\na\n\nl\n\n_\n\nc\n\no\n\nv\n\ne\n\nr\n\ns\n\n:\n\n \n\n[\n\n1\n\n2\n\n,\n\n1\n\n3\n\n]\n\n\n\n\n}\n\n\n\n\nT\n\na\n\ns\n\nk\n\n \n\nU\n\np\n\nd\n\na\n\nt\n\ne\n\n:\n\n \n\nP\n\nl\n\ne\n\na\n\ns\n\ne\n\n \n\nw\n\nr\n\ni\n\nt\n\ne\n\n \n\na\n\n \n\nm\n\ni\n\nn\n\ni\n\n-\n\na\n\nb\n\ns\n\nt\n\nr\n\na\n\nc\n\nt\n\n,\n\n \n\ns\n\nu\n\nm\n\nm\n\na\n\nr\n\ni\n\nz\n\ni\n\nn\n\ng\n\n \n\na\n\nn\n\nd\n\n \n\ne\n\nx\n\np\n\nl\n\ni\n\nc\n\ni\n\nt\n\nl\n\ny\n\n.",
